nameEntry.part: St Joseph's Catholic Orphanage for Girls
Orphanage Industrial School for Roman Catholic Girls

biogHist.abstract: St Joseph's Catholic Orphanage for Girls was established in Perth by the Sisters of Mercy in 1868, for girls from the Poor House. Children who were destitute were accommodated, along with orphans. In 1901, the Home moved to Subiaco and became the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage.
biogHist.p: An orphanage for Catholic girls was first established in 1868 when 11 girls were taken from the Poor House to live at the Sisters of Mercy Convent behind the Catholic pro-Cathedral in Victoria Avenue. By the end of that year, the convent had 27 children and no more room. A public appeal, supported by both Catholics and Protestants, raised &pound1400 for new premises. A new Convent of Mercy in Victoria Square was completed in 1871 and the orphanage was named St Joseph's Catholic Orphanage for Girls. In 1901, the orphanage moved to Subiaco and became the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage.

chronItem.event: Location - An orphanage for Catholic girls began in the Sisters of Mercy Convent on Victoria Square, Perth
Location - St Joseph's Catholic Orphanage for Girls opened in new premises, Convent of Mercy, Victoria Square, Perth
Location - St Joseph's Catholic Orphanage for Girls moved to the St Vincent's Boys' Orphanage site in Subiaco

descriptiveNote.p: The cost of raising a child in the Catholic Girls' Orphanage was examined by a Committee in the Legislative Council.
St Joseph's Catholic Orphanage for Girls began with girls transferred from the Female Home (Poor House, Perth).

archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of a document included in the Votes and Proceedings of the Parliament of Western Australia. It is from a bound and printed volume held by the State Records Office of WA.

This is a digital copy of a photograph of the Convent of Mercy, which is where the St Joseph's Catholic Girls' Orphanage began. It is from the State Library of Western Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Royal Western Australian Historical Society.
